repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Follow-up to #28490

Problem:

The new behaviour of goto_next/prev() of navigating to the next highest
severity doesn't work well when diagnostic providers have different
interpretations of severities. E.g. the user may be blocked from
navigating to a useful LSP warning, due to some linter error.

Solution:

The behaviour of next highest severity is now a hidden option
`_highest = true`. We can revisit how to integrate this behaviour
during the 0.11 cycle.

comment_regular_data.body:
> The behaviour of next highest severity is not opt-in by setting
`severity = 'auto'`.

Is it supposed to be "now opt-in"?

The point is that this behaviour should not be **default**.

If it's preferable, we can just remove this. The old behaviour was straight forward and intuitive and it's too late in the cycle to be making these kinds of changes.

> I still haven't seen an explanation of why users that want to opt-out of the behavior can't send a min/max filter. Why do we need a special-case "auto" severity?

Because the assumption that "this is what most people want" is simply false. `goto_next` implies _next_ diagnostic, not "most important diagnostic". If you are opposed to making this optional, the whole functionality needs to go. 

(I still think there's merit in adding an `auto` severity filter, as you _cannot_ know which severities you should filter on at the point of _setting_ the mapping, so this cannot be replicated simply with the filters we have.)

There is already an existing `severity_sort` option https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/a1c9da2d5af002ec5e9eb5ac1c0c61fc12ec4190/runtime/doc/diagnostic.txt#L438

Seems like goto_next behavior could be driven by that. Or goto_next should gain a `sort` option.

And then, sure, we can revert the current default behavior. And this will avoid severity=auto, which is just a different, unnecessary way to specify a "sort" strategy.
I think both are useful (as options, not defaults). That would be extensions, though, and hence not breaking (and not blocking 0.10).

> Seems like goto_next behavior could be driven by that. Or goto_next should gain a sort option.

I don't think this could work. What would be the semantics?

Given:

```
 |
E|
 | <cursor>
W|
```

What does `goto_next` do with the sort option enabled? Does it just do what `auto` does now?

I don't see how a severity-sort for goto_next can work - you'd need to introduce some additional state to remember where you were and what constitutes next.


As for default:

Given the backlash it looks like my assesment was off. If we don't want to add a `auto` option, we could go with https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/28552  instead?

For people who setup their own mappins setting `severity = { min = vim.diagnostic.severity.HINT }` wouldn't be too difficult.


just ftr, this is what I've been using up to now (it predates `diagnostic.count()`):

```
local function diagnostic_severity()
  local num_warnings = 0
  for _, d in ipairs(vim.diagnostic.get(0)) do
    if d.severity == vim.diagnostic.severity.ERROR then
      return vim.diagnostic.severity.ERROR
    elseif d.severity == vim.diagnostic.severity.WARN then
      num_warnings = num_warnings + 1
    end
  end
  if num_warnings > 0 then
    return vim.diagnostic.severity.WARN
  else
    return nil
  end
end


function M.next_diagnostic()
  vim.diagnostic.goto_next({
    severity = diagnostic_severity(),
    float = { border = 'single' }
  })
end
```


So if we don't want to add any new option, and don't want to change the default, users can get this auto behavior with a bit of Lua.

My suggestions came because I really think this is the better behavior. (And I also think that if the warning reports are more useful than the error reports, the linters are broken)

But I do not care about this strongly enough to continue arguing.

It would go to `E` first and then `W`. Yes, that would imply that `goto_{next,prev}` would have to keep state, which is a significant change and would have to be evaluated in detail. Certainly **not** something to consider before 0.10; just adding this as a possible way forward (instead of simply rolling back a well-intentioned change that did have some points in its favor, even if the total balance turns out to be negative).

For 0.10, I agree that reverting is the right thing to do so we can discuss the whole thing with sufficient time for 0.11.
Ok, so I've kept the code and tests, but hidden the feature under `opts._highest` which is undocumented.

> If we don't want to add a `auto` option, we could go with #28552 instead?
> 
> For people who setup their own mappins setting `severity = { min = vim.diagnostic.severity.HINT }` wouldn't be too difficult.

yes, that seemed like the obvious solution to me

> (And I also think that if the warning reports are more useful than the error reports, the linters are broken)

Diagnostic providers aren't aware of each other, and their interpretation of diagnostic severities are independent, somewhat arbitrary and usually just relative to other diagnostics they provide. E.g. Imagine if you had a spelling linter running: spelling errors would probably be errors and other minor mistakes (capital, grammar, etc) would be lesser.

And even if they are broken, that's not the users fault and the defaults we decide here shouldn't get in the way of that. Especially since the older default was absolutely fine.

> I assume that `_highest` will be replaced by some sort of `sort` option in the future.

Yes, it's just a placeholder. I didn't call it `sort` since it doesn't actually sort, it finds the highest diagnostic severity and navigates to the next closest one. The sorting is just an implementation detail to find the highest severity, which could be done more efficiently with a linear scan (not that would be required).

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(diagnostic): revert default behaviour of goto_next/prev()
